message_1: How many ways can 4 students be chosen out of a class of 20 students to represent their school in a mathematics competition if only 3 of them can be chosen?
message_2:
It seems there is a contradiction in the problem statement. If you want to choose 3 students out of 20, then the number of ways to do that is given by the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k! * (n-k)!)

where n is the total number of students (20 in this case) and k is the number of students to be chosen (3 in this case).

C(20, 3) = 20! / (3! * (20-3)!)
= 20! / (3! * 17!)
= (20 * 19 * 18) / (3 * 2 * 1)
= 1140

So there are 1140 ways to choose 3 students out of a class of 20 students.
